Frank,

It can all be done on a single chip. I'll work on a proto next week=
 when I get time.

-Sum

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Frank Sump=
tion 
  To: evp-itc@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Wednesday, November 28, 2007 4=
:47 PM
  Subject: RE: [EVP-ITC] RS 12-469 HackII Lives!


  Thanks, right n=
ow it's just an idea to try to find a solution of no or few radio stations =
in remote areas, such as the Stanley in Colorado. I could still use the whi=
te noise transistor, and schmitt trggers to convert pulse to random number,=
 the feed a 1 of 10 counter or something. I'm kinda behind on digital. I ha=
ve a PIC chip keyer, but bought it already programmed. 
   
   As wth all o=
f this stuff, I couldn't care less who actually does it.
   
   Frank-S



=


-------------------------------------------------------------------------=
---
    To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com
    From: w9sz@...
    Date:=
 Wed, 28 Nov 2007 16:56:26 -0600
    Subject: RE: [EVP-ITC] RS 12-469 HackI=
I Lives!



    I wrote the code for a pseudo-random number generator using=
 a PIC some 
    years ago. I'll see if I can dig it up.

    Zack

    On =
Wed, 28 Nov 2007, Frank Sumption wrote:

    >
    > Now all we need is a p=
ic chip to output random numbers which can be used to turn on and off switc=
hes that allow fixed tones through to a mixer/amplifier---Instant Spiricom!=
 I'm thinking use op amp square wave generators, and switch them in and out=
 using something like the old 4066 chips. The goal being to have a system t=
hat works without the presence of radio stations, such as remote investigat=
ions, and eliminate the concern that we're just creating the messages in ou=
r minds trying make sense out of random voice fragments.
    >
    > Frank-=
S
    >
